etymologies: Middle English: from the Old French stem round-, from a variant of Latin rotundus ‘rotund’

notes.text: On the difference in use between round and around, see around

definitions: shaped like or approximately like a circle or cylinder

examples.text: she was seated at a small, round table

shortDefinitions: shaped like circle or cylinder

definitions: having a curved shape like part of the circumference of a circle

examples.text: round arches

shortDefinitions: having curved shape like part of circumference of circle

definitions: shaped like or approximately like a sphere

examples.text: a round glass ball
the grapes are small and round

shortDefinitions: shaped like sphere

definitions: (of a person's body) plump

examples.text: he could move quickly despite his round physique

shortDefinitions: plump

definitions: having a curved surface with no sharp or jagged projections

examples.text: the boulders look round and smooth

shortDefinitions: having curved surface with no sharp projections

definitions: (of a voice) rich and mellow; not harsh

examples.text: his rich, round voice went down well with the listeners

shortDefinitions: rich and mellow

definitions: (of a number) altered for convenience of expression or calculation, for example to the nearest whole number or multiple of ten or five

examples.text: the size of the fleet is given in round numbers

shortDefinitions: expressed in convenient units rather than exactly

definitions: used to show that a figure has been completely and exactly reached

examples.text: a round dozen

shortDefinitions: used to show that figure has been completely and exactly reached

definitions: (of a sum of money) considerable

examples.text: his business is worth a round sum to me

shortDefinitions: considerable

definitions: (of a person or their manner of speaking) not omitting or disguising anything; frank and truthful

examples.text: she berated him in good round terms

shortDefinitions: not omitting or disguising anything

notes.text: On the difference in use between round and around, see around

definitions: a circular piece of a particular substance

examples.text: cut the pastry into rounds

shortDefinitions: circular piece of something

definitions: a thick disk of beef cut from the haunch as a joint.
shortDefinitions: thick disc of beef cut from haunch as joint

definitions: an act of visiting each of a number of people or places

examples.text: she did the rounds of her family to say goodbye
he made the rounds of the city's churches

shortDefinitions: act of visiting several people or places in turn

definitions: a tour of inspection, typically repeated regularly, in which the safety or well-being of those visited is checked

examples.text: the doctor is just making his rounds in the wards

shortDefinitions: regular tour of inspection in which well-being of those visited is checked

definitions: one of a sequence of sessions or groups of related actions or events, typically such that development or progress can be seen between one group and another

examples.text: the two sides held three rounds of talks

shortDefinitions: each of sequence of sessions in process

definitions: a division of a contest such as a boxing or wrestling match.
shortDefinitions: division of contest such as boxing

definitions: one of a succession of stages in a sporting contest or other competition, in each of which more candidates are eliminated

examples.text: the playoffs in the second round

shortDefinitions: each of succession of stages in competition, in each of which more candidates are eliminated

definitions: an act of playing all the holes in a golf course once

examples.text: Eileen enjoys the occasional round of golf

shortDefinitions: act of playing all holes in golf course once

definitions: a regularly recurring sequence of activities or functions

examples.text: their lives were a daily round of housework and laundry

shortDefinitions: regularly recurring sequence of activities

definitions: a set of drinks bought for all the members of a group, typically as part of a sequence in which each member in turn buys such a set

examples.text: it's my round

shortDefinitions: set of drinks bought for all members of group

definitions: a song for three or more unaccompanied voices or parts, each singing the same theme but starting one after another, at the same pitch or in octaves; a simple canon.
shortDefinitions: song for three or more unaccompanied voices or parts

definitions: the amount of ammunition needed to fire one shot

examples.text: the gun can fire 30 rounds a second

shortDefinitions: amount of ammunition needed to fire one shot

definitions: a fixed number of arrows shot from a fixed distance.
shortDefinitions: fixed number of arrows shot from fixed distance

notes.text: On the difference in use between round and around, see around
On the difference in use between round and around, see around
On the difference in use between round and around, see around

definitions: pass and go around (something) so as to move on in a changed direction

examples.text: the ship rounded the cape and sailed north

shortDefinitions: pass and go round something so as to move on in changed direction

definitions: alter (a number) to one less exact but more convenient for calculations

examples.text: we'll round the weight up to the nearest pound
the committee rounded down the figure
let's just round it off to an even ten dollars

shortDefinitions: alter number to one less exact but more convenient for calculations

definitions: give a round shape to

examples.text: a lathe that rounded chair legs

shortDefinitions: give round shape to

definitions: become circular in shape

examples.text: her eyes rounded in dismay

shortDefinitions: become circular in shape

definitions: pronounce (a vowel) with the lips narrowed and protruded

examples.text: the actor's uneven attempt to round the vowels of his midwestern twang

shortDefinitions: pronounce vowel with lips narrowed and protruded
